topic_metadata.title: Why bottom pad in paragraph breaks left pad in quote?

posts.name: Josí Neto
posts.cooked:
If I add a relative bottom padding to paragraphs via show rule, it breaks an absolute left padding to quotes, which gets then wrong size. A minimal working example:

#set page("a7") // just for presentation here
#show quote: set pad(left: 1cm)
A text.

#quote(block: true)[This quote gets correct padding.]

#show par: it => {
  pad(bottom: 1em, it)
}
#quote(block: true)[This quote gets wrong padding.]

mwe420×595 28.8 KB

Ideally, in fact, I would use a weak vertical space after every paragraph, not padding. I tried to do so with code below, but it doesn’t work. That’s why I resorted to the pad function. If anyone knows a better way to accomplish this, please let me know.

#show par: it => {
  it
  v(1em, weak: true)
}
posts.raw:
If I add a relative bottom padding to paragraphs via `show` rule, it breaks an absolute left padding to quotes, which gets then wrong size. A minimal working example:

```typ
#set page("a7") // just for presentation here
#show quote: set pad(left: 1cm)
A text.

#quote(block: true)[This quote gets correct padding.]

#show par: it => {
  pad(bottom: 1em, it)
}
#quote(block: true)[This quote gets wrong padding.]
```

![mwe|352x500, 75%](upload://v3obnjgwzHfcEi6Zwzca6LgFnQ7.png)


Ideally, in fact, I would use a weak vertical space after every paragraph, not padding. I tried to do so with code below, but it doesn't work. That's why I resorted to the `pad` function. If anyone knows a better way to accomplish this, please let me know.

```typ
#show par: it => {
  it
  v(1em, weak: true)
}
```

posts.name: Pascal Quach
posts.cooked:
Hello,
The way you are writing things results in the following code:

#set page("a7") // just for presentation here
#quote(block: false)[
  #set pad(left: 1cm)
  Not padded.
  #pad(bottom: 1em)[Padded.]
]

To explain further:

  1. The first show rule sets the left property of pad for the entire document.
  2. The second show rule wraps the content of any par in pad(bottom: 1em).

The two rules do not interfere with each other. You can read the documentation at Styling – Typst Documentation to get a better idea of how show rules work!

posts.name: SillyFreak
posts.cooked:
JosiNeto:

So, anyone has any idea why a paragraph’s bottom padding interferes (doubles) a quote’s left padding?

The problem, as I understand it, is that show quote: set pad(...) doesn’t just affect the specific pad that quote itself adds, but all pads inside the quote. Your second show rule adds another pad inside, so it also gets left: 1cm.

Unfortunately I’m not sure how to best fix this cleanly. As a workaround, you can manually specify left: 0em for that pad, I wouldn’t consider that clean really clean…
posts.raw:
[quote="JosiNeto, post:3, topic:600"]

[/quote]

The problem, as I understand it, is that `show quote: set pad(...)` doesn't just affect the specific `pad` that quote itself adds, but all `pad`s inside the `quote`. Your second show rule adds another `pad` inside, so it also gets `left: 1cm`.

Unfortunately I'm not sure how to best fix this cleanly. As a workaround, you can manually specify `left: 0em` for that `pad`, I wouldn't consider that clean really clean...

posts.cooked:
Yeah, there is one pad already existing: typst/crates/typst/src/model/quote.rs at 40fcd97d584fc1dfa6446bc4922d3b1e440e0afd · typst/typst · GitHub. The second one would wrap the whole quote. So there are 2 pad elements in total. And since the show-set rule is global, it applies to both pads. Which indeed will explain why left padding has a x2 multiplier when it gets set.

You probably don’t need a second pad, so I would write the last show rule like this:

#show quote: set pad(bottom: 1em)

Otherwise, the solution given by @SillyFreak is probably your next best bet.

github.com/typst/typst

Paragraph spacing property

typst:main ← typst:par-spacing
opened 03:48PM - 13 Jun 24 UTC
laurmaedje
+155 -99

This introduces a new `par.spacing` property. Paragraphs are [not considered `bl…ock`s anymore](https://github.com/typst/typst/pull/4310) and are not affected by `block.spacing`. Instead `block.spacing` now delegates to `par.spacing`, when it is `auto` (the new default). If, however, it is set to a non-auto value, it has precedence over paragraph spacing. This change has the following benefits: - Changing the paragraph spacing (and by extension the default block spacing) becomes simpler in the common case: `#set par(spacing: ..)` instead of `show par: set block(spacing: ..)`. - Previously, `block.above` and `block.below` created spacing with higher priority (and thus possibly different results) than `block.spacing` because otherwise it was impossible to override a larger spacing (e.g. for a heading to reduce the spacing below it). This was confusing. In the new system, `spacing` is really just a shorthand for `above` and `below` since these naturally have higher priority than paragraph spacing (and thus also `auto` block spacing, which is the same). - Because we can remove the internal hack, `block.above` and `block.below` are now available in context expressions. `par.spacing` is of course available as well. Moreover, I changed `list.spacing`, `enum.spacing`, and `terms.spacing` to select `leading`/`spacing` based on their tightness when set to `auto`, but to always respect the set value otherwise. Previously tight lists always ignored the `spacing` property. I believe the original reasoning was that `set list(spacing: ..)` shouldn't break tight lists, but this problem is better solved with `show list.where(tight: false): set list(spacing: ..)` in my opinion. I also improved the docs on `par.leading` and fixed a small bug with `quote` related to its block spacing.

@laurmaedje, do you know what’s the problem here?
